mydescriptions[0]="This hoverfly is mimicking a bee. Hoverflies eat aphids and are gardener's friends.";
mydescriptions[1]="This wasp-like hoverfly fools predators into thinking it is dangerous. It isn't!";
mydescriptions[2]="This is a tiny pod midge which attacks oilseed rape crops. Notice how furry the midge's antennae are.";
mydescriptions[3]="This carabid ground beetle is a ferocious predator. It likes eating slugs.";
mydescriptions[4]="This male stag beetle is about 4cm long and is the UK's biggest insect.";
mydescriptions[5]="Beetles with long 'noses' like this are called weevils. This is a seed weevil.";
mydescriptions[6]="This is a ladybird beetle showing her wings. Ladybirds use their wing cases (elytra) to protect their delicate folded wings.";
mydescriptions[7]="This is a parasitic wasp injecting an egg into an aphid. The egg hatches and eats the aphid from the inside out.";
mydescriptions[8]="This parasitic wasp preys on caterpillars. It can lay a lot of eggs in one caterpillar.";
mydescriptions[9]="This is a very tiny parasitic wasp. Some parasitic wasps are so small you can hardly see them.";
mydescriptions[10]="This is a lacewing. Lacewings are rather primitive insects which are beneficial because they eat aphids.";
mydescriptions[11]="This is a tiger moth. Its bright colours give a warning to birds that it tastes horrible.";
mydescriptions[12]="This is a beautiful peacock butterfly. Notice how hairy it is!";
mydescriptions[13]="This is a butterfly tagged with a radar antenna. Radar is being used to see where butterflies fly.";
mydescriptions[14]="This is a butterfly feeding on oilseed rape flowers. Butterflies have very long tongues which they use to drink nectar from flowers.";
mydescriptions[15]="This is a honey bee taking a drink of water. Honey bees have very sensitive taste buds.";
mydescriptions[16]="This is a bumblebee feeding on a flower. Bees have to drink a lot of nectar to get the energy they need to fly.";
mydescriptions[17]="This is a close up of a bumblebee's face. Bumblebees are furry to keep them warm so they can fly early in the morning and late at night.";
